title-group.article-title: Finite element simulation of projectile perforation through a ballistic fabric

article-meta.aff: 1The University of Manchester, School of Materials, Sackville Street, Manchester, UK
2Heriot-Watt University, School of Textiles, Galashiels, UK
3Defence Equipment and Support UK, Personal Combat Equipment Team, Neighbourhood 4, Bristol, UK
4Dstl UK, Physical Sciences Department, Salisbury, Wiltshire, UK

author-notes.corresp: Xiaogang Chen, The University of Manchester, School of Materials, Sackville Street, Manchester M13 9PL, UK. Email: xiaogang.chen@manchester.ac.uk

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A finite element (FE) model is developed to simulate the ballistic impact of a flat-faced cylindrical projectile onto a flexible plain woven fabric made from Kevlar. The geometric model of the fabric was made by an in-house CAD programme known as UniverWeave© on the specification of actual structural parameters of a fabric. Commercial software package ABAQUS was used to simulate the projectile–fabric impact process assuming that the constituent yarns are elastic and plastic when loaded. Comparison between the experimental and the simulated results revealed that the developed model for projectile–fabric impact using ABAQUS/Explicit is effective to simulate the ballistic impact process with high accuracy. The dynamic mechanisms of the impacted fabric were studied. It showed that the projectile lost its velocity quickly at the beginning and then decreased slowly. The cone formed in the backface of the impacted fabric is virtually linear with respect to time. The cone radius increased rapidly at the very beginning of the impact and less significant afterwards. A smaller cone base radius was found to correspond to a higher velocity impacted fabric. It also has been found that the main forms of energy absorption are the kinetic energy of the cone, the plastic and elastic energy of the impacted fabric. Furthermore, it is believed that a specified fabric can be designed and engineered against a certain level of threat based on the finding that there exist a specific impact energy under which the fabric absorbs maximum projectile impact energy.

body.p: Innovations in high-performance fibres have been the driving force for developments in body protection against ballistic threats. Fabrics made from high-performance fibres, such as aramid and high-performance polyethylene, have been widely used in flexible body armours, leading to better protection, lighter weight, and better designs.

During the ballistic impact onto textile-based body armour, cone formation in the layers of fabrics takes place on the exit side of the target headed by the point of impact.1–3 This is the result of the transverse wave propagation caused by the impact. The surface radius of the cone increases with time. Also, the cone grows and develops further as the projectile moves forward. As a result, the height of the cone increases. The projectile displacement and the cone height at any instant of time would be the same. Variation of the cone surface radius with time was reported by Naik et al.1 Initially, the transverse wave velocity increases significantly and then remains nearly constant during the remaining period of the ballistic impact event. The increase of cone surface radius is almost linear with respect to time whereas the increase of the cone height with time is nonlinear. The rate of increase of cone height/depth slows down with time, which is associated with the velocity variation of the projectile during the ballistic impact event.

In an impact situation, the strong impact pulse on the surface of the target is reflected as a tensile wave4 and if the magnitude of the tensile stress it causes is greater than the tensile strength of the materials, fractures occur and that causes material separation. If after fracture the magnitude of the stress pulse still exceeds the material’s tensile strength, multiple fractures can occur. As the intensity of the applied load increases, the material is driven beyond its elastic limit and becomes plastic. Two waves propagate in the fabric material, which is elastic wave (or precursor) followed by a much slower but more intense plastic wave, termed as the longitudinal wave and transverse wave, respectively.

In a longitudinal pulse the particle motion is parallel to the direction of propagation of the pulse and the strain is pure dilatation. In a transverse wave, otherwise called a distortional, rotational, secondary, or shear wave, the particle motion is normal to the direction of propagation of the pulse and the strain is a shearing strain.4

Propagation speeds of the longitudinal and transverse wave formed on the panel of the protective material during ballistic impact is related to the energy absorption ability of fabric. The ability of fabric layers in energy absorption and propagation is dependent on the tensile modulus of fibres and yarns as well as the fabrics. The tensile modulus along with tensile strength of yarns is the main parameter affecting ballistic performance. At present, the materials used for making personal protective body armour are ballistic nylon, para-aramid (e.g. Kevlar® and Twaron®) and Ultra High Molecular Weight Polyethylene (UHMWPE) (e.g. Dyneema® and Spectra®).5 All of these are continuous multi-filament yarns, with high modulus, high strength, suitable extensibility and lightweight.

Both non-woven and woven fabric structures of various types are being used either with or without resin matrices for ballistic applications. Two-dimensional woven fabrics constructed by interlacing warp and weft yarns at 90° are the most commonly used structures for ballistic applications. Basic two-dimensional fabric constructions are the plain, twill and satin weaves. Among them, the plain weave fabric exhibits the highest level of fabric tightness, followed by twill and then satin weave. Therefore, the dimensional stability of plain weave is the highest among these three basic structures.5

In parallel to ballistic tests which are used for evaluation, design and optimization of ballistic materials, finite element (FE) models have also been developed to simulate the ballistic impact onto body armour materials. This has been an important alternative method to characterise the fabrics for ballistic protection. Many researchers have developed fabric structural models to explore their mechanical properties and ballistic impact behaviour. The shell element-based computational approach was reported by Shahkarami and Vaziri.6 They modelled the response of multi-layer fabrics to ballistic impact while accounting for the detailed geometrical and material properties of the fabric panels described by such parameters as crimp, yarn geometry at a crossover and transverse compression of yarns. Duan et al.7 found through modelling that the friction between yarns in fabric are beneficial to enhance the ballistic performance of a fabric during ballistic impact. Shim et al.8,9 investigated the effect of yarn crimp via FE modelling on the ballistic properties of fabrics. A viscoelastic material model was developed by Tan et al.10 to describe the mechanical behaviour of the yarns including failure in the situation of ballistic impact. A material model was employed in the computational simulation of ballistic penetration of woven aramid fabrics. Result comparison between the simulations and actual ballistic tests showed that predictions of the energy absorbed by the fabric were in good agreement with the experiments. Gu11 studied the ballistic penetration of projectiles into Twaron plain woven fabric and concluded that the interspaces between the warp and weft yarns do not reduce the absorption of the projectile kinetic energy by the target fabric.

The event of high-speed projectile impact on a flexible target fabric is a complex phenomenon.12 The complexity comes from the high number of intervening parameters such as impact velocity, shape and mass of the impactor, location of impactor–target contact, dimensions and boundary conditions, target material characteristics and so on. Such features lead to distinctive failure modes of the ballistic material. FE simulation of high-speed projectile–fabric impact can be performed with little difficulty, but the important issue in numerical studies of impact on and perforation through ballistic materials and structures is the accuracy in material and structure definition.

This paper reports a recently developed FE simulation model based on practical fabric parameters and on simulation result on the dynamic response of the ballistic fabric when impacted by a high-velocity projectile. The simulation will be used to find information for ballistic fabric engineering which is not easily obtained through experiments. In this research the FE model is assumed to be at yarn level. ABAQUS, a commercial FE package, is employed to simulate the ballistic impact process. Three-dimensional geometrical models for warp and weft yarns and the subsequent fabrics are created by a CAD program UniverWeave© developed at the University of Manchester. Based on the validated model, the relationship between the impact energy and the dimension of the cone formed during ballistic is investigated. The important energies absorbed by the fabric are studied. The information provided will help in ballistic fabrics engineering.

sec.title: Geometric model development and material specification
sec.p:
In this FE model, eight warp and eight weft Kevlar yarns, organized together using the plain weave, are included in the fabric geometric model which is shown in Figure 1, created by using UniverWeave©.13 The yarn density and the structural parameters of the fabric are listed in Table 1, which are the same as the real fabric used for ballistic test. In order to save computational resources, only a quarter of the projectile and fabric specimen (containing eight warp and eight weft yarns) are considered. The 3D geometric model of the plain woven fabric created by UniverWeave© was then saved in IGES file format, which can then be imported to CAD/CAM packages such as ABAQUS®. The FE model is composed of three parts. The first is the eight warp yarns, the second is the eight weft yarns and the third part is a quarter of the cylindrical projectile with diameter and length both being 5.56 mm which are the same as the projectile used for practical ballistic test. For rendering and meshing purposes, warp and weft yarns were imported separately in precise representation forms and then assembled to form the plain woven fabric. To avoid meshing and post-processing problems caused by the enormous element faces of the yarns, four faces were made for each yarn by combining the small element faces together, which are the top face, back face and the two cross-sections at the end of each yarn. Figure 1.
Geometric model of ballistic fabric and projectile.
Table 1.
Input parameters in UniverWeave© for warp and weft yarns
Linear density (tex) Fibre density (g/cm3) Warp/weft density (threads/cm) Yarn crimp (%) Yarn cross-section Yarn state
158 1.44 7.6 2.2 Lenticular Solid

Material properties of the three parts were defined after the geometric model was established. The material properties required for input are shown in Table 2 based on the experimental result from yarn tensile test and data from literature. Each Kevlar yarn of 158 tex is composed of over 900 Kevlar filaments with diameter of 12 µm, although it is assumed to be in solid state. Table 2.
Materials’ properties input in ABAQUS/explicit.
Material properties Kevlar (warp and weft yarns) Steel (1/4 projectile)
Density (×10−9 tonne/mm3) 1.44 7.85
Young’s modulus (MPa) 93,328 210,000
Poisson’s ratio 0.36 0.3
Fracture strain (%) 4.368
Damage evolution energy (mJ) 72
Yield stress (MPa) 3301.6
Plastic strain at yield stress (%) 0.411

sec.title: Mathematical model of progressive damage
sec.p: A progressive damage model which reflects the material property degradation is implemented in ABAQUS®/Explicit. The simulation of failure of materials consists of three stages, which are (i) establishment of a damage initiation criterion, (ii) determination of a damage evolution law and (iii) a choice of element removal upon reaching a completely damaged state. The damage initiation criterion allows the connectivity of the elements to change during impact. In the model of element deletion, failure is considered to occur at the element level, on the basis of strain, stress or combined stress–strain criteria.14 In order to represent quantitatively the effects of the intermediate stages of damage development, models with distributed damage are used. An evolution equation for damage is necessary to complete the model and must be integrated together with the equilibrium equations.

The progressive damage model assumes that when the element fails, it can no longer carry stress and then its contribution to yarn strength should be removed and a new iterative analysis has to be carried out. The applied load is progressively increased after load redistribution of element failure.

The failure of a material is usually classified into brittle failure (fracture) or ductile failure (yield). The stress-based ductile damage criterion is used to detect the failure mode in the fabric and yarn under both stress and plastic strain. The model assumes that the equivalent plastic strain at the onset of damage ɛ¯D pl is a function of stress triaxiality and strain rate: ɛ¯D pl(η,¯·ɛpl) , where η=-p/q is the stress triaxiality, p is the pressure stress, q is the Mises equivalent stress, and ¯·ɛpl is the equivalent plastic strain rate.

The criterion for damage initiation is met when the following condition is satisfied: (1)ωD=∫dɛ¯plɛ¯D pl(η,¯·ɛpl)=1 where ωD is a state variable that increases monotonically with plastic deformation. At each increment during the analysis the incremental increase in ωD is computed as (2)ΔωD=Δɛ¯plɛ¯D pl(η,¯·ɛpl)≥0

When material damage occurs the stress–strain relationship no longer accurately represents the material’s behaviour. Hillerborg et al.’s fracture energy proposal is then used to reduce mesh dependency by creating a stress-displacement response after damage is initiated.15 Hillerborg et al. define the energy, Gf, required to open a unit area of crack as a material parameter and it is given in Equation (3) (3)Gf=∫ɛ¯0 pl ɛ¯f plLσydɛ¯pl=∫0 u¯plσydu¯pl where L is the characteristic length, u¯pl=L¯·ɛpl is the equivalent plastic displacement, σy is yield stress.
An exponential evolution of the damage variable, d, based on energy dissipated during the damage process is given below: (4)d=1-exp (-∫0 u¯plσ¯y¯·uplGf )

The formulation of the model ensures that the energy dissipated during the damage evolution process is equal to Gf. In theory, the damage variable reaches the value of 1 only asymptotically at infinite equivalent plastic displacement.

sec.title: Interactions, boundary conditions and parts meshing scheme
sec.p: There are three parts in the finite element model, which are the warp yarns, weft yarns and the projectile. Contacts are specified between the projectile and warp/weft yarns and between warp and weft yarns. The projectile is defined as the master surface, and the warp and weft yarns are defined as slave surfaces. General contact (Explicit) is selected for calculations. The analytical rigid surface of the projectile is used in the general contact algorithm, which provides a smoother surface description that reduces contact noise and is a better approximation of the physical contact constraint. This is because the projectile used in the ballistic tests does not deform significantly during penetration into one layer (and more layers) of fabric.16,17

Boundary conditions are defined on each part of the boundary by specifying components with respect to a local coordinate system defined by the orthogonal basis. Displacement boundary conditions (fixed surface) are used. The initial conditions, which describe the state of a body at the start of an analysis specifying the position and velocity at the initial time, are taken as zero. The boundary conditions are then specified as described below. For the projectile, the translational freedom along X and Y-axes and the rotational freedom along the Z-axis are constrained and set to zero, i.e. vx = vy = 0. The translational freedom perpendicular to the symmetrical plane and the rotational freedom in the symmetrical plane are constrained and set to zero, namely Ux = URy = URz = 0 and Uy = URx = URz = 0 are used, respectively. The one quarter of the target fabric circumference is fixed, i.e. Ux = Uy = Uz = URx = URy = URz = 0.
For a 3D solid analysis the elements have physical thickness in all three dimensions.

Fabric warp and weft yarns and projectile are all meshed by a three-dimensional four-node linear tetrahedron solid element C3D4 (stress/displacement element in ABAQUS®) as yarns in the woven fabric have irregular geometries especially in the presence of yarn crimps and floats. The tetrahedron element is designed for meshing complex shapes such as the lenticular-shaped yarns with crimps present.

sec.title: Ballistic impact test
sec.p:
Ballistic impact tests were carried out using a firing range at the University of Manchester. Single-layered fabric targets were impacted by a cylindrical steel projectile, which the FE simulation adopted accordingly, at velocities of up to 530 m/s. The projectile passes through the first pair of infrared (IR) projectile detectors before impacting the fabric target and then the second pair of IR detector after perforation. Time lengths t1and t2 for the projectile to pass through the front and back pair of detectors were recorded by the two digital timers connected to the two pair of detectors, respectively. The projectile impact velocity vi and residual velocity vr are then calculated as follows: (5)vi=s1t1
(6)vr=s2t2 where s1 and s2 are the distances between the two detectors of the front and back pairs of projectile detectors, respectively. Five samples of the target fabric were tested ballistically.

sec.title: Residual velocity of projectile
sec.p:
Using the FE model established in this research, the residual velocities of the projectile can be obtained through post-processing of the established model, upon the specification of the impact velocities obtained from practical impact test. The residual velocities of the projectile perforating a single-layer target fabric, obtained from practical testing and FE simulation responding to various impact projectile velocities are presented in Table 3 and Figure 2. It can be seen that as the impact energy goes higher, the residual velocity of the projectile is higher in both experimental and simulated cases. It is also demonstrated that the theoretical residual velocities are invariably higher (maximum 4.3%) than the experimental ones. It is easy to understand the former of the two findings. The latter is believed to be due to the assumption used in the FE modelling. It was assumed that the warp and weft yarns are solid in the FE model, whereas in reality there are 956 Kevlar filaments each 12 µm in diameter and friction exists among the filaments. Under the idealized assumptions which are used for the FE simulation, less energy was absorbed by the FE simulated fabric than the real fabric. However, there is a significant linear relationship between FE simulated and experimental results on the residual velocity of the projectile. This is shown in both Equation (7) and Figure 3: (7)y=0.9939x+10.42
Figure 2.
Comparison of residual velocity of the projectile in FE simulation and experiment.
Figure 3.
Correlation between simulated and experimental residual velocities.
Table 3.
Comparison of residual velocity of experiment and simulation under the same impact velocity
Impact velocity (m/s) 488.57 494.22 506.47 520.49 528.68
Experimental residual velocity (m/s) 468.91 468.31 478.84 496.57 506.29
Simulated residual velocity (m/s) 471.94 477.60 490.06 504.18 512.52

In Equation (7), y is residual velocity from FE simulation and x is the corresponding residual velocity from experiment. The correlation coefficient of the residual velocity between the experimental and simulated velocities is 0.9835, indicating that the experimental and theoretical results are highly correlated.

sec.title: Longitudinal stress wave in impacted target fabric
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the longitudinal stress wave in the simulated impact on the single-layer fabric. Time moments of t1 = 0.251 µs and t2 = 1.201 µs are chosen in order to estimate the longitudinal wave speed as the wave propagates between elements E41899 and E41725 in a principal warp yarn when impacted at a velocity of 494.217 m/s. The distance between the two elements is d = 5.143 mm, and therefore the average speed of the longitudinal stress wave propagating along the principal yarn is vfab=dt2-t1=5413.68 m/s. The longitudinal stress wave speed v has been presented by the following equation, when the projectile impacts the yarn transversely, by Lyons:19 (8)v=Eρ where E is the Young’s modulus and ρ is the material volumetric density. Figure 4.
Stress wave front reaches (a) element 41899 and (b) element 41725 at specific time moments.
Roylance and Wang19 found that the longitudinal stress wave speed vfab in a fabric is a fixed fraction of the stress wave speed in a single fibre: (9)vfab=vα

The value α may be attributed to the effective increase of the linear density of a yarn in the fabric caused by the crossovers of yarns. In the plain woven fabric, the linear density of the yarn along which a wave is propagating is effectively doubled.20 Therefore, the longitudinal stress wave speed in a warp or weft yarn of the plain woven fabric is v=Eρ divided by a factor of α=2 .

From Equations (8) and (9) the longitudinal stress wave speed can be calculated as 5693.45 m/s, where the Young’s modulus of Kevlar yarn E and volumetric density ρ are taken as 93328 MPa and 1.44 g/cm3, respectively. A difference of 5.2% is found between the finite element calculations and Lyons’ theory.

From the discussions above on the simulated and experimental residual projectile velocities and on the speed of the longitudinal stress wave in the ballistic fabric, it can be concluded that the developed FE model for projectile–fabric impact using ABAQUS/Explicit is able to simulate the ballistic impact process with satisfactory accuracy.

sec.title: Deformation of fabric
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the deformation of the target fabric during ballistic impact at different time points during the whole impact process, under the projectile impact velocity v0 = 494.217 m/s. Figure 5.
Fabric perforated by the projectile and stress distribution at different step time points (a) t = 0 µs, (b) t = 0.75 µs, (c) t = 1.37 µs, (d) t = 5.25 µs, (e) t = 6.0 µs and (f) t = 8.12 µs.

Figure 5(a) shows the initial state of the projectile–fabric model. Immediately upon impact, a shock wave is created on the fabric surface centred at the impact location. The shock wave is reflected as a stress wave from the distal surface as seen in Figure 5(b). Yarns in the fabric are deflected in the direction of motion of the projectile. Figure 5(c) shows that a longitudinal strain is formed from the impacted area, and the wave is propagated outwards to the edge of the fabric model along the warp and weft yarns through the impact vicinity. A cone is formed in the backface side of the fabric. Figure 5(d)–(f) show that the cone base area increases with impact time. During the impact process, yarns extend and slip against those in the other direction. As a result, stress spreads into a larger area through the yarn crossovers between warp and weft, and this propagates strain to the adjacent warp/weft yarns. Figure 5(d) shows that the strain in the yarns starts to exceed the dynamic breaking strain, leading to partial failure in yarns. Figure 5(e) and (f) show the further development of the strain in principal yarns around the cone area, causing more yarns to break. As a result, the projectile perforates the fabric with a reduced residual velocity.

Figure 6 is the deformed fabric sample after experiencing ballistic impact. The sample size was 24 cm × 24 cm. The shape of the fabric sample has been changed from time to time during ballistic impact and a short time after the impact which was caused by movement of the fabric sample. Similar to the FE simulated result, a cone was formed on the impacted fabric and yarn breakage occurred for the yarns in the contacted area by the projectile. Figure 6.
Fabric sample after experiencing ballistic impact.

sec.title: Projectile velocity
sec.p:
At the initial stage of the impact, the projectile quickly loses its velocity and hence the kinetic energy it carries. The loss of the projectile kinetic energy is considered the same as the energy absorbed by the fabric in many different forms, such as kinetic energy, plastic energy, elastic energy and damage energy. The FE simulation indicated that the energy loss from the projectile slows down with time, as can be seen in Figure 7. The longer the yarns are to endure the impact before failure, the larger the amount of deformed area becomes and the greater the energy absorbed by the target fabric. It is important to emphasize that the sharp edge of the cylindrical penetrator causes localized damage, which was described by Zohdi and Powell.20 The projectile velocity remains almost constant once the target fabric is perforated. According to Figure 7, the perforation of the fabric occurred at around 7 µs after the projectile–fabric impact. Figure 7.
Projectile velocity as a function of time.

sec.title: Height and radius of the back face deformation
sec.p: During the ballistic impact, the target fabric deforms in the direction of the projectile travelling, and this is caused by the transverse stress wave propagation. The cone-shaped deformation develops along with the projectile, which absorbs energy. The height and base radius of the cone increase during the impact process. The height and base radius of the cone are important parameters to indicate the ballistic performance of a fabric. A large base radius formed in the impacted fabric means effective dissipation and absorption of the impact energy and a small cone height suggests small blunt trauma caused by the impact.

The distance travelled by the projectile in each time interval Δhi is given by (10)Δhi=vi-1Δt-12ai (Δt2 ) where vi-1 is the projectile velocity at time ti-1 , Δt is the duration of time interval that total impact time is divided into and ai is the deceleration of the projectile.
Then the distance travelled by the projectile up to the ith time interval hi can be obtained by (11)hi=∑n=0 n=iΔhi

Owing to anisotropy of woven fabrics, the shape of cone base in the fabric is roughly a diamond shape. The kinetic energy Ei of the part of the fabric involved in the cone at time i can be expressed as (12)Ei=12mivi 2 where mi and vi are the mass and velocity of the moving cone shape at the ith impact time point, respectively. The mass of the moving shape mi can be estimated from the areal density of the target fabric and the surface area of the cone: (13)mi=14ρπriri 2+hi 2 where ρ is the areal density of the fabric, ri is the surface radius and hi is the height of the cone. According to Equations (12) and (13), the radius of the cone base can be expressed as (14)ri=12-hi 2+hi 2+256Ei 2ρ2π2vi 4

Figure 8(a) shows that the backface deformation (i.e. the cone) height development is virtually linear with respect to impact time. As described in Figure 8(b), the cone radius increases rapidly at the beginning of the impact (at about 1 µs after the impact) and the change of the cone radius afterwards with respect to time becomes much less significant. Based on the structural feature of the woven fabrics, it is reasonable to believe that the sharp increase of the cone radius is due to the straightening of the yarn crimp, and that the slowing down of cone radius increase is a reflection of the yarn/fibre taking on load. Figure 8(b) also shows that the final cone base radius at the failure of the target fabric is smaller when the impact velocity is higher. This indicates that for a given fabric, a higher impact velocity leads to a more localized fabric deformation. Figure 8.
(a) Cone height at impact velocity of 494.217 m/s and (b) cone radius at various impact velocities.

The FE simulation also confirms that the maximum cone height at fabric failure is proportional to the impact velocity of the projectile, and this is shown in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Maximum cone height of the impacted fabric against impact velocity.

sec.title: Energy absorption in the projectile–fabric model
sec.p:
Figure 10 shows the projectile kinetic energy and energy absorbed by the fabric at different impact time with the impact velocity being 494.217 m/s. The initial slope of the two curves is quite steep. This means that the projectile loses its kinetic energy rapidly when impacted onto the fabric; the lost energy is transformed into different forms of energy, mainly strain energy and kinetic energy, in the target fabric. The composition of energy absorbed by the fabric against time is shown in Figure 11. The fact that the two curves in Figure 10 are symmetrical is a proof that the energy loss of the projectile is an accurate measure of the energy absorption by the fabric. Figure 10.
Projectile kinetic energy loss and fabric energy absorption.
Figure 11.
Composition of the absorbed energy by the fabric (vp = 494.217 m/s).

During the projectile–fabric impact process, the cone moves forward and grows in size when the projectile travels forward. Before impact takes place, the energy absorption by the fabric is zero. Immediately after the impact of the projectile onto the fabric, fabric kinetic energy increases rapidly and so is the strain energy (sum of elastic and plastic energy). These are illustrated in Figure 11, and energy absorption is a result of the high velocity impact and of the longitudinal and transverse waves induced by the projectile impact. It can be seen that the kinetic energy carried by the fabric remains more or less the same after impact and started to decrease after projectile penetration (at about 7 µs), whilst the plastic energy keeps increasing during the whole impact process. The latter is an indication of the existence of increased plastic deformation in yarns and fibres because of the cone development. The elastic deformation, mainly caused by the longitudinal stress, increases at the early stage of the impact and then is kept virtually constant during the rest of the process. Energy absorbed by fibre and yarn breakage is not in existence until about 3.5 µs into the impact, and this energy reaches its maximum when the projectile penetrates the fabric at round 7 µs. One important piece of information provided by the FE simulation is that the energy absorbed by fabric fracture, i.e. the damage energy, is relatively small, about only 5% of the total energy absorption of the fabric.

The relationship between energy absorbed by the fabric and the projectile impact energy at various velocities obtained from the FE simulation is shown in Figure 12. It is evident from Figure 12 that the decrease of the projectile kinetic energy is associated with the increase of energy absorbed by the fabric for all impact velocities. This means that the loss of the projectile kinetic energy is converted into the energy absorbed by the impacted target fabric. The total energy absorbed by the fabric depends on the initial kinetic energy carried by the projectile. It is of interest to note that the relationship between the total fabric energy absorption and the change of kinetic energy carried by the projectile is linear, regardless of the initial impact velocity. Figure 12.
Energy absorbed by the fabric versus projectile kinetic energy.

Figure 13 depicts the final total energy absorption of the fabric against the initial kinetic energy carried by the projectile. It shows that highest impact energy may not necessarily lead to highest energy absorption of the fabric. The FE simulation suggests that there exists a level of impact energy that would lead to a maximum energy absorption by the fabric. In this context, this threshold value of the impact energy is termed the peak of the projectile impact energy, Epeak, and at this energy level maximum energy will be absorbed by the same fabric concerned. Below or above Epeak, the fabric will absorb less energy. In Figure 13, Epeak = 36 J for the simulated target fabric. A similar phenomenon is also observed in an actual ballistic test, the result of which is shown in Figure 13, where the fabric specifications are all the same as the simulated fabric apart from the fabric dimension. The difference in impact energy in Figure 13 and 14 is due to the fact that the FE model uses only a quarter of the projectile impacting onto a quarter of the fabric due to geometrical symmetry of the projectiles. More detailed discussions on the influence of these factors on energy absorption of the fabric are beyond the scope of the paper. However, the experimental tests confirmed the energy absorption trend revealed by the FE simulation. Figure 13.
Energy absorbed by fabric at various impact energies from FE simulation.
Figure 14.
Energy absorbed by the fabric at various impact energies from experiment.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
A FE analysis model of the rigid projectile impacting on a single-layer Kevlar® fabric has been successfully generated. The validation shows that the residual velocities of the projectile between the theoretical and experimental values are highly correlated, with the correlation coefficient being 0.9835. The mechanisms of the projectile–fabric impact have been studied through simulation, leading to the following conclusions:
The projectile loses its velocity quickly at a very early stage of the impact, and the velocity decreases slowly afterwards and remains constant after perforation.
A cone is formed in the backface side of the target fabric caused as a result of the transverse stress wave. The cone height is virtually linear with respect to time; the maximum height of the cone increases proportionally with the impact energy. The cone radius is increased rapidly at the very beginning of the impact and less significant afterwards. It also shows that a higher impact velocity results in a smaller final cone base radius.
The projectile kinetic energy is transferred into various forms of energy absorbed by the target fabric during the projectile–fabric impact. The main forms of energy absorption are the kinetic energy of the developing cone, the plastic and the elastic energy of the impacted fabric. While energy absorbed by the fabric fracture only accounts for a small proportion of the energy in comparison.
For a given target fabric there exist a specific impact energy under which the fabric absorbs maximum projectile impact energy. This implies that a specified fabric can be engineered against a certain level of threat.

ZhuGGoldsmithWDharanCK. Penetration of laminated Kevlar by projectiles. I. Experimental investigation. Int J Solids Struct 1992; 29: 399–420.
MoryeSSHinePJDuckettRACarrDJWardIM. Modelling of the energy absorption by polymer composites upon ballistic impact. Composites Sci Technol 2000; 60: 2631–2642.
